lead_paragraph: The Government announced today that, beginning next March 1, blacks paying income tax in South Africa would no longer have to do so at higher rates than whites. The announcement was made by Finance Minister Owen Horwood in presenting the Government's annual budget to Parliament in Cape Town.

snippet: To the Editor:   In his review of Thomas Laqueur's "Making Sex" (Dec. 9), Melvin Konner questions the extent to which men and women were considered sexually identical during ancient and medieval times. To support his argument, he poses the questio...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In his review of Thomas Laqueur's "Making Sex" (Dec. 9), Melvin Konner questions the extent to which men and women were considered sexually identical during ancient and medieval times. To support his argument, he poses the question "Did . . . women in ancient cities [ pay ] men for sex as often as men paid women?" While I agree with much of what Dr. Konner has written, I would like to add the following point. In male-dominated societies in which women were prohibited from owning land and inheriting wealth and had little access to professions, a woman who chose or was forced to generate an income independently had only one thing to sell: herself. By the same token, a woman did not have the means to buy sexual pleasure. I suggest that the roots of female prostitution have less to do with differences between male and female sexuality and the desire for pleasure than with economic power. JANET R. SPARROW New York

headline.main: The Roots of Prostitution

snippet: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A changing population and a changing industrial structure are producing a persistent trend toward inequality in the distribution of income among wage and salary earners in the United States, a study published by the Labor De...
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A changing population and a changing industrial structure are producing a persistent trend toward inequality in the distribution of income among wage and salary earners in the United States, a study published by the Labor Department has found.
abstract: Labor Dept study by P Henle finds that changing population and indus structure in US are producing persistent trend toward inequality in income distribution among wage and salary earners; trend is toward concentration of increasingly large share of avg wage and salary income among people in jobs and professions that already bring higher pay; unlike most studies of income, which examine family earnings, Henle study examines only money earnings of male workers; using unpublished data from Census Bur, study finds that from '58-70 the share of aggregate wage and salary income earned by lowest 5th of male workers declined to 4.60% from 5.10%; at same time, share of highest 5th of male wage and salary earners rose to 40.55% from 38.15%; Henle, in telephone int, says trend reflects tendency in econ to produce more higher-paying jobs without reducing number of lower-paid workers; comments on some factors; suggests Govt could ameliorate problem through manpower training and antidiscrimination and other programs to 'open way for individuals to advance up earnings ladder'; study findings reptd in Labor Dept Monthly Labor Rev

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: One aspect of the sorry stories of unpaid alimony and child support is the rarely revealed male practice of underreporting earnings to the Internal Revenue Service, the courts and former spouses' attorneys. This does more than deny desperately needed funds to newly poor households of women and children: it removes money from national tax coffers.

headline.main: Sometimes Dad Is a Better Parent; To Beat the Verdict

snippet: At a time when consumption is less conspicuous than it used to be, today's sure-fire clue to status is not what's being worn but what isn't. A New Yorker realized that one cold and rainy day this week when he started to look for a luncheon guest's...
lead_paragraph: At a time when consumption is less conspicuous than it used to be, today's sure-fire clue to status is not what's being worn but what isn't. A New Yorker realized that one cold and rainy day this week when he started to look for a luncheon guest's topcoat. There wasn't one -- because said luncheon guest had a limo waiting outside. But of course! The limo waiting outside explains why some women still wear high heels long after the rest of femalekind has descended to Nikes. Why they carry purses just big enough for a lipstick, handkerchief, a few bills and a credit card. Why they and their male counterparts forgo raingear. They need only walk the several paces from curb to restaurant door; they can leave their bags and briefcases in the back seat; and wherever there's a chauffeur-driven car there's sure to be a doorman with an umbrella. To spot a healthy income or healthy bank account, then, look for less. It's more.

snippet: To the Editor:    Of the five dads who commented in the article, four were caring for children at or over preschool age. Many women, after a brutal financial calculation, conclude that any income they earned from working would be canceled out by f...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Of the five dads who commented in the article, four were caring for children at or over preschool age. Many women, after a brutal financial calculation, conclude that any income they earned from working would be canceled out by fees for preschool or child care programs. They therefore stay at home, preferring to spend time with their growing children.

snippet: To the Editor:    You call the increase in the number of single women with children ''troubling'' (''The Changing American Family,'' editorial, May 18).     Yes, the increase in the number of unplanned children born to low-  and moderate-income wo...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You call the increase in the number of single women with children ''troubling'' (''The Changing American Family,'' editorial, May 18). Yes, the increase in the number of unplanned children born to low- and moderate-income women and girls whose male partners make minimal or no contribution to their children's upbringing may be cause for concern. But doesn't the term ''single mothers'' also include professional women who choose to get pregnant and raise their kids, and women who can afford to adopt children?
abstract: Amy J Weinblatt letter on May 18 editorial on decline of nuclear family notes that term 'single mother' includes professional women who choose to raise child on their own

snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''More Men's Teams Benched as Colleges Level the Field'' (front page, May 9), about the effort to achieve athletic equality for women's teams:    A larger issue is how much should a college invest in athletics given its primar...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''More Men's Teams Benched as Colleges Level the Field'' (front page, May 9), about the effort to achieve athletic equality for women's teams: A larger issue is how much should a college invest in athletics given its primary mission. For the many colleges and universities in which athletic expenses exceed revenues, tough choices must be made to ensure that the educational value of athletics is weighed against the educational value of math and literature, genetics and microeconomics.
abstract: Letter from William E Cooper, president, Univ of Richmond, comments on May 9 article on effort to achieve athletic equality for women's teams in college sports

snippet: The Census Bureau set the White House aglow this week when it reported that in 1996 median income rose for the second consecutive year while black and Hispanic poverty rates fell. President Clinton said the report proved that his economic policies...
lead_paragraph: The Census Bureau set the White House aglow this week when it reported that in 1996 median income rose for the second consecutive year while black and Hispanic poverty rates fell. President Clinton said the report proved that his economic policies were working and that the middle class was finally on the rise. But a deeper look at the census report finds a gloomier perspective -- the middle class is not doing very well and the poor are falling further behind. The backdrop for the report is an economy that has steadily recovered since 1991 and is growing at a healthy 3 percent a year. Unemployment has dropped below 5 percent to its lowest level in a quarter-century. Inflation is low and falling. Welfare rolls fell almost 10 percent last year. The minimum wage is rising. The economic landscape could not be better for middle-class families in general, and low-wage workers in particular.
abstract: Editorial notes that Census Bureau set White House aglow when it reported that in 1996 median income rose for second consecutive year while black and Hispanic proverty rates fell; disputes Pres Clinton's contention that report proves that his economic policies are working; maintains that deeper look at census report finds that middle class is not doing very well and poor are falling further behind (M)

headline.main: The Tide Is Not Lifting Everyone

snippet: For women, the pay gap between the educational haves and have-nots has widened inexorably over the last two decades. In 1980, high-school dropouts earned 57 percent as much as college graduates, but by 1998 that ratio had slid to 40 percent.     M...
lead_paragraph: For women, the pay gap between the educational haves and have-nots has widened inexorably over the last two decades. In 1980, high-school dropouts earned 57 percent as much as college graduates, but by 1998 that ratio had slid to 40 percent. Minority women are catching up in education: in 1998, almost as many Hispanic women (41 percent) and black women (56 percent) had at least some college, as did white women (60 percent).
abstract: Pay gap for women between educational haves and have-nots had widened over last two decades, in 1980, high-school dropouts earned 57 percent as much as college graduates, but by 1998 that ratio slid to 40 percent; minority women have continued to lag income, no matter what their education, but Hispanic women have done significantly better than black women; graphs (M)

headline.main: Women's Earnings: What a Difference a Degree Makes
